original_title: Sri Lanka opposition, COPF to discuss DDO
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s committee on public finance (COPF) is expected to discuss a domestic debt restructuring plan on June 29 and 30 its chairman Harsha de Silva said.

The cabinet is expected to consider the debt plan this week and the parliament is expected to have weekend sessions on July 01 and 02, based on information available, de Silva who chairs the COPF said.
President Ranil Wickresinghe has also updated the leader of the opposition and himself up to an extent, he said.
Sri Lanka’s opposition parties are to meet on Monday to discuss domestic debt restructuring.
“We said from the beginning that it is better not do restructure domestic debt” de Silva told reporters.
“But if it is essential to do it, we have said that the financial system stability has to be protected and deposits should be protected.”
“There should not be a hair cut. We will not agree to a hair-cut.”
Sri Lanka has to re-structure domestic debt to meet borrowing and debt rollover ceilings (Gross Financing Need) set by the International Monetary Fund in a debt sustainability analysis.

Sri Lanka has monetary instability due to a dual anchor conflicting regime (targeting inflation while collecting foreign reserves) found in a number of unstable countries which have chronic forex shortages, reserve losses, social unrest and default.(Colombo/June26/2023 – Update II)
